Name: Sojourner Truth
WD_Description: African-American abolitionist and women's rights activist
E_Description: Enslaved. A traveling evangelical preacher, she took the name Sojourner Truth and became a leading feminist and abolitionist who also helped African Americans find employment outside of the south. She also initiated multiple lawsuits.

Name: Olaudah Equiano
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Also known as Gustavus Vassa, Equiano survived the Middle Passage, bought his freedom, and became a prominent abolitionist who is considered to have authored the first full-length slave narrative.

Name: Stephen Bishop
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Enslaved as a guide in Mammoth Caves who had extensive knowledge of the underground cave system.

Name: Jupiter Hammon
WD_Description: American writer and first known published African-American author
E_Description: Enslaved. The first published African American poet and an advocate of gradual emancipation.

Name: Pierre Toussaint
WD_Description: Haitian-American hairdresser (1766–1853); declared Venerable by Pope John Paul II
E_Description: Born Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Born enslaved in Saint-Domingue and brought to New York, Toussaint became a successful barber and philanthropist who was a devoted Catholic. His biography was written by a white friend, Hannah Farnham Sawyer Lee.

Name: William Wells Brown
WD_Description: American abolitionist lecturer, novelist, playwright, and historian
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. An abolitionist, member of the Underground Railroad, autobiographer, travelogue writer, and author of Clotel (considered to be the first full-length African American novel) who also lectured in the U.S. and Great Britain .

Name: William Lee
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. A personal valet to George Washington and a talented horseman, Lee gained his freedom late in life but remained at Mount Vernon.

Name: Salem Poor
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Fought so valiantly at the Battle of Bunker Hill that fourteen officers submitted a petition for him to be rewarded.

Name: Anthony Burns
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. The subject of the most widely publicized fugitive slave case, Burns eventually became a Baptist clergyman in Ontario.

Name: Clara Brown
WD_Description: American formerly enslaved person, community leader, philanthropist (1800–1885)
E_Description: Enslaved. Community leader in Colorado.

Name: Hannah Crafts
E_Description: Enslaved. Cross-listed as "Hannah Bond".

Name: Henry Box Brown
WD_Description: American magician, illusionist, actor and former slave
E_Description: Born Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Made a daring escape from slavery by traveling in a box, an event that he later incorporated in his career as a performer.

Name: Henry Highland Garnet
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. A temperance and antislavery activist who lectured in the U.S. and Great Britain. Also a university president, the first African American to preach a sermon in the White House, and U.S. minister to Liberia.

Name: Thomas Peters
WD_Description: Black Loyalist founding father of Sierra Leone
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. A West African-born Loyalist who was resettled to Nova Scotia after the Revolutionary War, Peters traveled to London in 1790 to petition the resettlement of Nova Scotia blacks to West Africa. 1200 individuals joined Peters in migrating to Sierra Leone.

Name: Samuel Ringgold Ward
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. A teacher, preacher of several congregations (one of which was all-white), and a traveling lecturer for the American Anti-Slavery Society, and newspaper editor.

Name: Absalom Jones
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. The first black person to become an Episcopal priest, Jones was also an organizer of the Free Africa Society (in Philadelphia), an abolitionist, and ultimately an opponent of the American Colonization Society.

Name: Amos Fortune
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Enslaved and transported to America c. 1725, Fortune later became a tanner, a bookbinder, and a freedman.

Name: Archer Alexander
WD_Description: formerly enslaved person and statue model (~1810-1879)
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Described by William Greenleaf Eliot's The Story of Archer Alexander. From Slavery to Freedom, March 30, 1863 and portrayed in the Freedmen's Memorial to Abraham Lincoln, Archer was a fugitive slave who helped members of his family escape slavery.

Name: Bethany Veney
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Enslaved in several different families, Veney finally gained her freedom in 1858 and after the Civil War returned to find other family members. She dictated an autobiography at the age of 74.

Name: Charlotte Dupuy
WD_Description: African American plaintiff in freedom suit
E_Description: Enslaved. Also known as Lotty.

Name: David George
E_Description: Born Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Minister at one of the first black Baptist churches in the U.S., George continued his preaching in Nova Scotia after the Revolutionary War but encountered racism there as well and in 1792 led almost 1,200 black Baptists to Sierra Leone .

Name: George Moses Horton
E_Description: Born Enslaved. Enslaved North Carolinian. The first African American poet whose work centers on the struggle for freedom .

Name: Mary Fields
WD_Description: first African-American female Star Route stagecoach delivery driver the United States
E_Description: Born Enslaved. First African American woman to drive a coach for the postal service. Became a business owner at age 70. A frontierswoman who drank, smoke, and got in a shootout.

Name: Jermain Wesley Loguen
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. A school founder who was ordained by the AMEZ Church in 1842 and became a bishop in 1868, Loguen was also a member of the Radical Abolition Society who by his own account helped over 1,500 runaway slaves. .

Name: John Jea
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. The author of a significant autobiography, Jea toured, preached, and held revivals in the U.S., while at sea, during multiple European tours, and in the West Indies.

Name: Jordan Winston Early
E_Description: Born Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. An AME minister who undertook dangerous missionary work in the South, converted hundreds of people, and became presiding elder in parts of Tennessee.

Name: Kate Drumgoold
E_Description: Enslaved. Autobiography is notable for flattering description of white employers, and for its description of her life moving between the South and North.

Name: Lewis Hayden
WD_Description: American abolitionist, lecturer, businessman and politician (1811-1889)
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. A traveling lecturer for the American Anti-Slavery Society who ran a successful clothing store in Boston, helped fugitive slaves, lobbied for the creation of a black regiment during the Civil War, and was elected in 1873 to the Massachusetts senate.

Name: Lott Cary
WD_Description: American slave who helped found Liberia
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. A Baptist preacher who served as a missionary in Liberia and in 1828 was appointed acting governor of the more than 1,200 settlers.

Name: Moses Roper
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. He escaped to the north via the "maritime Underground Railroad" and then traveled to England in 1835, where he became a lecturer and author.

Name: Patrick Francis Healy
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. A Roman Catholic priest who, upon finishing his studies at Catholic University of Louvain in Belgium in  26 July 1865, apparently became the first African American to earn a PhD. He was also the first African American Jesuit and served as the 29th president of Georgetown.

Name: Polly Berry
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment.  Her daughter Lucy Ann Delany wrote a memoir about her. From Darkness Cometh Light; or Struggles for Freedom (1891),  https://docsouth.unc.edu/neh/delaney/menu.html .

Name: Prince Estabrook
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Estabrook participated in the Battle of Lexington and is the first known African American who fought in the War of Independence.

Name: Prince Whipple
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. After being enslaved and transported to North America, Prince petitioned unsuccessfully in 1779 to end slavery and then participated in the American Revolution. Some credited him with crossing the Delaware River with Washington in December 1776, though this is unsubstantiated.

Name: Scipio Moorhead
E_Description: Enslaved. One of the first African American painters, Moorhead is best known for his engraving of Phillis Wheatley. Also a poet.

Name: Seymour Burr
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Possibly born in Africa and later enslaved by the family of Aaron Burr's brother, Burr earned his freedom by fighting in the Revolutionary War.

Name: Shadrach Minkins
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Minkins was the central figure in one of the  most famous Fugitive Slave Law cases in Boston.

Name: Solomon Bayley
E_Description: Born Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. A former slave and abolitionist speaker whose experiences were recorded in Narrative of Some Remarkable Incidents in the Life of Solomon Bayley, Formerly a Slave, in the State of Delaware, North America, Bayley later immigrated to Liberia with his wife.

Name: Thomas Fuller
E_Description: Enslaved. A prodigy at mental math.

Name: Thomas Sims
E_Description: Enslaved. Sims became widely known during an unsuccessful effort by abolitionists to prevent his re-enslavement under the Fugitive Slave Act. After the war he worked as a mason and held various patronage jobs.

Name: Venture Smith
WD_Description: Colonial American enslaved African and author
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Captured in Guinea and forced to be a servant in raids on other African nations, and at age eight was transported to Rhode Island and enslaved there. After gaining his freedom he wrote an important autobiography and acquired land.

Name: William Harvey Carney
WD_Description: United States Army Medal of Honor recipient
E_Description: Free before 13th Amendment.

Name: William Henry Singleton
E_Description: Enslaved. A sergeant in the First North Carolina Colored Regiment (later called the Thirty-fifth Regiment, U.S. Colored Troops) who became a coachman and traveling Methodist minister after the war.

Name: Josiah Henson
WD_Description: Author, abolitionist, and minister. Born into slavery, in Port Tobacco, Charles Co., Maryland, he escaped to Upper Canada (now Ontario) in 1830.
E_Description: Born Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. An escaped slave who became a pastor, led a community of escaped slaves, wrote an autobiography and possibly was the basis for the character of Uncle Tom in Harriet Beecher Stowe's famous novel.

Name: Mahommah Gardo Baquaqua
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Born in a Muslim merchant family in West Africa, he escaped from slavery in Brazil and later became an antislavery lecturer and author of an autobiography with an important account of the Middle Passage.

Name: Madison Hemings
WD_Description: American freed slave, son of Thomas Jefferson and Sally Hemings (1805-1877)

Name: Harriet Powers
E_Description: Born Enslaved. Made narrative quilts with Christian themes.

Name: Moses Grandy
WD_Description: African American author, abolitionist, and slave
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. Experienced many family separations while enslaved. Later dictated his narrative to raise funds for his family's freedom.

Name: Mary Black
WD_Description: slave in the household of Nathanial Putnam
E_Description: "MARY BLACK was indicted for feloniously stealing . . . "

Name: Onesimus
E_Description: Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment.Onesimus taught his former owner about a smallpox inoculation technique developed in Africa, and in light of the latter's promotion 600 Bostonians were inoculated.

Name: William Grimes
E_Description: Born Enslaved. Free before 13th Amendment. After being enslaved by ten owners, Grimes escaped and became a barber in New Haven, Connecticut, moving several times to avoid re-enslavement.
